findings.title: iOS client is susceptible to URI scheme hijacking
findings.description: The Uniswap mobile app defines the `uniswap://` URI scheme for receiving messages from other apps on the device, which can be hijacked by another app if the malicious app registers the same scheme and is also installed on the device.

findings.title: The iOS client does not disable custom keyboards
findings.description: The Uniswap mobile app client does not disable custom keyboards which can log and exfiltrate user-entered data.

findings.title: Encrypted iCloud backups use low-entropy keys
findings.description: The six-digit pin used for encrypting iCloud wallet backups has low entropy, making it vulnerable to brute-force attacks. An attacker could potentially decrypt the file and gain control of user funds.

findings.title: Users are allowed to create unencrypted iCloud backups
findings.description: An attacker can gain control of all user assets by accessing the unencrypted mnemonic via phishing campaign or iCloud exploit.

findings.title: Remote timing side channel in WalletConnect library
findings.description: The vulnerability affects the mobile wallet by potentially allowing a malicious WalletConnect bridge to forge message requests, including changing the token amounts in valid DApp requests and tampering with wallet responses to queries of balances and other blockchain states.

findings.title: Use of libraries with known vulnerabilities
findings.description: The codebase contains outdated dependencies affected by critical and high-risk vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Sending funds to user-owned addresses can cause spurious warnings
findings.description: Presenting the user with many warnings can lead to 'alert fatigue' and encourage the user to dismiss future warnings without consideration.
findings.contract: Uniswap iOS Wallet token send modal

findings.title: WalletConnect v1 reuses cryptographic keys for multiple primitives
findings.description: The WalletConnect v1 specification requires clients to communicate using AES-CBC for encryption along with HMAC-SHA256 to authenticate data, both computed using a single shared symmetric key.

findings.title: Credentials checked into source control
findings.description: Sensitive credentials, including a hard-coded mnemonic, are checked into source control in the Uniswap mobile repository, which could result in loss of funds if leaked.

findings.title: NFTs with SVG images are rendered as HTML
findings.description: An attacker can serve arbitrary HTML on the URI associated with the token and cause the wallet to render it on a WebView, allowing requests to external hosts or navigation to other external sites.

findings.title: Application does not exclude keychain items from iCloud and iTunes backups
findings.description: The Uniswap mobile wallet does not prohibit its keychain items from being saved to an iTunes backup or uploaded to iCloud, exposing private data such as mnemonic phrases and private keys for accounts.

findings.title: ShakeBugs may leak mnemonic
findings.description: The Uniswap mobile wallet uses ShakeBugs to help with reporting of issues in the app. When a user reports an issue, ShakeBugs can take a screenshot and send it along with the reported issue. If this happens in a screen that shows a mnemonic, the user’s mnemonic would be logged to ShakeBugs.

findings.title: Use of improperly pinned GitHub Actions in Testflight build
findings.description: The GitHub Actions workflows for creating an iOS application build uses several third-party actions that are pinned to a tag or branch name instead of a full commit SHA, enabling repository owners to silently modify the actions.

findings.title: Typos
findings.description: There are several typos in files.

findings.title: Uniswap URI Scheme Hijacking
findings.description: The app does not make use of Universal Links, thereby allowing the uniswap:// URL to be hijacked.

findings.title: Use of custom iOS keyboards is not disabled
findings.description: The GitHub Actions workflow used to build and publish the application do not use hashes to identify external GitHub actions to execute.

findings.title: HTML Sanitization Issue
findings.description: HTML is not sanitized when displaying an NFT’s SVG image

findings.title: Sensitive Wallet Information Exposure
findings.description: Sensitive wallet information stored in Keychain, such as mnemonic, is not prohibited from being included in backups of iCloud or iTunes, allowing an attacker with access to iCloud or iTunes to access sensitive wallet data.

findings.title: Weak Encryption of Wallet File
findings.description: The encryption of a user’s wallet file uses a low-entropy key that can be easily brute-forced, allowing an attacker who has gained access to a user’s iCloud to decrypt the wallet file and gain access to the mnemonic.

findings.title: Wallet File Encryption Option
findings.description: Users are given the option not to encrypt their wallet file, allowing an attacker with iCloud access to steal the mnemonic.

findings.title: Not Found
findings.description: Finding not found in provided audit report fragments.

findings.title: N/A
findings.description: Finding not present in provided audit report fragments.

findings.title: Outdated Packages with Known Security Issues
findings.description: Many outdated packages with known security issues were identified, indicating an ineffective package management policy or checks performed in the CI/CD pipeline.

findings.title: GitHub Actions Workflow Security
findings.description: The GitHub Actions workflow used to build and publish the application do not use hashes to identify external GitHub actions to execute.

findings.title: Multiple Credentials Stored in Git Repository
findings.description: Credentials are stored in the Git repository which is a security risk.

findings.title: Mnemonic Disclosure through Screenshots
findings.description: The views that display the mnemonic are not marked as 'private.' As such, screenshots taken for the ShakeBugs service can include a user's mnemonic.
